title: Boston ranks among best U.S. cities for Thanksgiving â€” and tops New England
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Boston ranked 18th in WalletHub's list of top 100 U.S. cities for Thanksgiving.
Boston's restaurant scene contributed to its lone New England city ranking in the top 20.
The city excelled in volunteerism and charity, boosting its 'Giving Thanks' score.

title: Five years after debuting ‘Java with Jimmy,’ host James Hills isn’t slowing down
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: James 'Jimmy' Hills started 'Java with Jimmy' to engage with the community during the COVID-19 pandemic five years ago.
Hills interviews political figures and community leaders on his show, which now includes regular calls from Mayor Michelle Wu.
Hills expresses a long-term commitment to 'Java with Jimmy' and aspires to expand into a community-focused platform.

title: Roman Anthony earns a third place finish for AL Rookie of the Year
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Roman Anthony finished third in the AL Rookie of the Year voting, behind Athletics' Nick Kurtz and Jacob Wilson.
Anthony debuted on June 9, hitting .292 with eight home runs and 32 RBIs in 71 games before an oblique injury.
Despite finishing third, Anthony signed an eight-year, $130 million extension with the Red Sox in August.

title: Federal judge orders release of Fitchburg woman detained by ICE in viral video
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: A federal judge ordered the release of Juliana Milena Ojeda Montoya, detained by ICE in Fitchburg, Massachusetts.
Ojeda Montoya's arrest video went viral, leading to her habeas corpus petition and questioning the applicability of the Laken Riley Act.
The Department of Homeland Security accused her husband of faking a medical emergency during the arrest; she faces assault charges.

title: How Mass. lawmakers are reacting to the deal that could end the government shutdown
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Massachusetts lawmakers criticize the Senate's funding deal due to lack of health care subsidy extensions.
Rep. Seth Moulton calls for new Senate leadership over health care concessions in the shutdown deal.
Reps. Katherine Clark and Jim McGovern oppose the deal, citing harmful economic impacts on families.

title: Boston firefighters battle 2-alarm blaze at multi-family home in Dorchester
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: A two-alarm fire at 25 Train St. in Dorchester displaced two residents on Tuesday morning, with no injuries reported.
The Boston Fire Department extinguished the fire by 9:30 a.m.; damages are estimated at $500,000.
One firefighter was hospitalized, and the cause of the fire is under investigation by the Boston Fire Investigation Unit.

title: Here’s what Jon Stewart had to say about the Senate Democrats voting to end the shutdown
author: John Waller
bullets: Jon Stewart criticized Senate Democrats for ending the government shutdown, calling their action a 'world class collapse.'
The Senate Democrats voted to end the federal government shutdown, which drew commentary from entertainment figures like Jon Stewart.
The Senate has taken initial legislative steps to conclude the federal government shutdown, sparking reactions from public figures.

title: Patrice Bergeron was asked about possible 2026 Hall of Fame induction
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Patrice Bergeron, former Bruins captain, may be eligible for the 2026 Hockey Hall of Fame induction.
Bergeron retired in 2023 after 19 NHL seasons, winning six Selke Trophies and a Stanley Cup with the Bruins.
Bergeron humbly supports Zdeno Chara and Joe Thornton's Hall of Fame inductions, downplaying his own candidacy.

title: Boston police ask for help in search for missing 15-year-old
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Boston police request public assistance in locating missing 15-year-old Briyana Jacques from Dorchester.
Briyana Jacques was last seen near Ashmont station and 1300 Blue Hill Ave. on Saturday afternoon.
She is described as a Black female, 5'5", thin build, with brown hair and blonde highlights, wearing a black jacket and grey sweatpants.

title: Struggling military families ask Globe Santa for help
author: Linda Matchan
bullets: Military families facing financial hardship are seeking assistance from Globe Santa for holiday gifts.
Rising living costs, unemployment, and inadequate stipends are causing financial strain for families stationed in Massachusetts.
Globe Santa, run by the Boston Globe Foundation, has supported children in need for 70 years.
